Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Nationwide Life Insurance Company agreed to settle allegations that it routinely violated pricing rules in its daily processing of purchase and redemption orders for variable insurance contracts and underlying mutual funds.
misclassification

Description: Nationwide agreed to pay more than $19 million to settle allegations that it violated the Fair Credit Reporting Act by increasing auto insurance premiums of some customers based on information contained in consumer-credit reports and then failed to notify the insureds of those adverse actions.

Description: insurance coverage dispute

Info Source: Attorney General Patrick Morrisey Announces $5.75 Million Settlement With Nationwide Insurance, Targeted News Service, July 2, 2015 (via Nexis).

Description: Nationwide agreed to pay $650,000 as part of settlement of allegations it deceived consumers into buying policies beyond their financial means.
Nationwide agreed to pay $7.2 million to settle multistate litigation regarding its use of the Social Security Administration's Death Master File.
Info Source: Florida Announces Multi-Agency, Multi-State Agreement with Nationwide Insurance Companies -- $144 Million Already Returned to Consumers, Targeted News Service, October 11, 2012 (via Nexis).

Description: Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company and its subsidiary, Allied Property & Casualty Insurance Company, agreed to pay $5.5 million to settle multistate litigation concerning an October 2012 data breach that the states alleged had been caused by the failure to apply a critical security patch.
